title: Operators & Expressions
description: Learn arithmetic, logical, and comparison operators to build expressions

concepts.title: Arithmetic Operators
concepts.content:
Arithmetic operators perform mathematical operations on numerical values. C provides the basic operations you learned in mathematics: addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modulus.

The addition operator (+) adds two numbers together. For example, 5 + 3 equals 8. The subtraction operator (-) subtracts the second number from the first. So 10 - 3 equals 7. The multiplication operator (*) multiplies two numbers, where 4 * 5 equals 20.

The division operator (/) divides the first number by the second. When both operands are integers, the result is also an integer with any decimal part discarded. For example, 7 / 2 equals 3 (not 3.5). If you want the decimal result, at least one operand must be a floating-point number: 7.0 / 2 equals 3.5.

The modulus operator (%) gives the remainder after division. For example, 7 % 2 equals 1 because 7 divided by 2 is 3 with a remainder of 1. This is useful for checking if a number is even (number % 2 == 0) or for cycling through values.

These operators follow the standard order of operations (PEMDAS): multiplication and division are performed before addition and subtraction. You can use parentheses to override this order, just as in mathematics. Understanding operator precedence is important to avoid unexpected results in your calculations.
concepts.codeExample:
int a = 10, b = 3;
int sum = a + b;        // 13
int diff = a - b;       // 7
int prod = a * b;       // 30
int quot = a / b;       // 3 (integer division)
int rem = a % b;        // 1 (remainder)

concepts.title: Comparison Operators
concepts.content:
Comparison operators compare two values and return a true or false result. In C, true is represented by 1 and false is represented by 0.

The equal to operator (==) checks if two values are the same. For example, 5 == 5 is true, but 5 == 3 is false. Don't confuse this with the assignment operator (=), which assigns a value to a variable.

The not equal to operator (!=) checks if two values are different. So 5 != 3 is true, but 5 != 5 is false.

The less than operator (<) checks if the first value is smaller than the second. 3 < 5 is true, but 5 < 3 is false. The greater than operator (>) checks if the first value is larger. 5 > 3 is true.

The less than or equal to operator (<=) and greater than or equal to operator (>=) combine the inequality checks with equality. So 3 <= 3 is true, and 5 >= 5 is true.

These operators are essential for making decisions in your programs through conditional statements like if and while. They let your program respond differently based on the values of variables.
concepts.codeExample:
int a = 10, b = 5;
int equal = (a == b);      // 0 (false)
int notEqual = (a != b);   // 1 (true)
int lessThan = (a < b);    // 0 (false)
int greaterThan = (a > b); // 1 (true)
int lessOrEqual = (a <= b);    // 0 (false)
int greatOrEqual = (a >= b);   // 1 (true)

concepts.title: Logical Operators
concepts.content:
Logical operators combine multiple conditions into a single true or false result. They're essential for making complex decisions in your programs.

The AND operator (&&) returns true only if both conditions are true. For example, (5 > 3) && (2 < 4) is true because both conditions are true. But (5 > 3) && (2 > 4) is false because the second condition is false. This operator is useful when you need multiple conditions to all be satisfied.

The OR operator (||) returns true if at least one condition is true. For example, (5 > 10) || (2 < 4) is true because the second condition is true, even though the first is false. This operator lets your program proceed if any of several conditions are met.

The NOT operator (!) reverses the truth value. If a condition is true, !condition is false, and vice versa. For example, !(5 > 10) is true because (5 > 10) is false.

These operators follow a specific precedence: NOT is evaluated first, then AND, then OR. You can use parentheses to make your logic clearer and override this precedence. Logical operators are fundamental to controlling program flow and making intelligent decisions based on multiple criteria.
concepts.codeExample:
int age = 25, hasLicense = 1, hasInsurance = 1;
int canDrive = (age >= 18) && hasLicense && hasInsurance;  // 1 (true)
int goodStudent = (gpa > 3.0) || (studentAge < 20);          // depends on values
int isNotAdult = !(age >= 18);                               // 0 (false)
